9.15.20  2:47 pm   you said the first letter of your new song is h

     that's not true

     and the second letter is l but there are no words that go hl are you inventing language

     sometimes a little, but not for this song

9.15.20  2:43 pm   hi bill, do you have any advice on what to do if you don't feel like you are well enough suited to do a task but you still desire to accomplish said task?

      try doing it anyway. UNLESS there are extreme danger risks of doing it imperfectly. which is not the case with most tasks, but it is for some tasks, like flying a spaceship

9.15.20  2:37 pm   Is there life on Venus?

      maybe

9.15.20  2:19 pm   any thoughts on your song In California?

     yes

     I think i read that it was made a little after history of the entire world, but it kinda has the early bill wurtz vibe

     here are my thoughts about it. it is an interesting case study in deadlines vs non deadlines, it's also an interesting case study in brute force randomized song selection, and it's also a good case study in making arrangement adjustments at the very last moment.
     deadlines vs non deadlines:
     i knew the entire time when i was making history of the world that i wanted to do songs constantly, forever, and i wanted to do this before history of the world, but history of the world became unexpectedly more important. so the entire time i had the idea that i was going to do songs next. so finally when i was done, i immediately jumped into the song. i had a general idea that i was going to use a weekly deadline, but i wasn't ready to do it quite yet. i wanted to take my time and do it 'right'. i got some good things, the initial groove/vamp sound was found then, and some other things, but after several days, maybe even a week, i felt everything slowing down, and i couldn't seem to make good decisions anymore. so i suddenly set a deadline and then demanded to do them weekly after that. Immediately after setting that deadline, i suddenly made a bunch of bold instrumental choices that wouldn't have been made otherwise. some of the percussion fills in the first verse, a lone loud bongo bonk, a hyper spaz hi-hat fill followed by a huge crash, if i remember correctly those are examples of decisions i made immediately after declaring being on a deadline.
     brute force randomized selection:
     usually if i try to select the next song without randomized assistance (like, actually choose which one i want to do) it's usually a downward spiral into rejecting everything. every song is too this or too that. too weak, too intense, too emotional, to dumb, too smart, too slow, too fast, too weird, too normal, etc etc. And i have no courage to take any risks. So the alternative to this is just getting a brute force random number. count all the songs in the list, (at this time it was something like 400), and get a computer generated random number from that range, and you MUST do that song. Well, i was willing to accept the result, but the problem here with the result (california) is that the song features a massive marijuana reference. This would be ok except for the fact that i had already had multiple marijuana references in songs before that. Ultimately i went forward with the selection because i felt like i had no other choice, but this highlights a problem with brute force random selection. Yes, it helps you avoid thinking EVERY song is 'wrong', but there's a weird fine line to reckon with because some songs ACTUALLY are 'wrong', considering the previous songs. For example, this song being about california, the following song (also chosen with brute force random) was called "i love you". Well, there is also a song in the list called "California Love" which has nothing to do with those other two. So, imagine for a moment, if "California Love" was picked next, after those other two. that would be terrible, it would look like an obvious deliberate themed connection, which it is not. fortunately the randomizer did not pick that, and the next 2 choices turned out ok. and since then i have developed a hybrid system that allows me to mostly rule out any of these problems before the randomized selection is made
     making arrangement changes at the last moment:
     usually, after the instrumental arrangement is done, and the vocals are done, and mixing is done, and i'm in the final troubleshooting stage, there can be an extreme resistence against going back and changing things in the arrangement. you just don't want to re-open what seems like a sealed box. but occasionally it has to be done, and i've learned that i MUST let myself be open to that. this song is a good example: those synth riffs in the background of the "it's alright" parts. Those were added at the very end. like during the final adjustments / mixing / troubleshooting phase. i opened the arrangement again to add those riffs there. and it made a huge difference
     some additional thoughts about the writing:
     it's important to point out that this song was essentially written in august 2011 (about 6 years before it was recorded). So this may slightly change the way the lyrics are perceived. Marijuana was not fully legal in any state at that time. and the reason it is about California is because that is the state that was most well known for marijuana usage at the time, because i think it had recently become legal medically. For every other state mentioned in the song, i'm pretty sure, it was still very illegal, especially in Alabama which i believe had some of the toughest marijuana laws at the time. One of the reasons i featured it in the second verse. Also, the final line of the song (love who you want to) was certainly a reference to the legalization of gay marriage, which at the time was only legal in certain places, which is another thing California was known for at the time

9.15.20  1:53 pm   is the new song done?

      yes but i reserve the right to make some eq adjustments if i feel like some of the snares and hihats get too ear piercing at certain times. but i won't have objectivity on this until i've worked with it in the video department for a little while
